content.description:
Start on easy gear protected climbing past horizontals moving slightly right. Once you reach the first bolt, move left into a technical crux through underclings and sidepulls on bad feet. Pleasant moderate climbing leads to a bolted anchor (only hangers currently, alternatively scramble to the tree).



Locate the bolt line that ends on a ledge 3/4 of the way up the cliff.

.3-.75 BD, 6 bolts

climbs.name: Dry Spell
climbs.fa: E. Sloan, F. Corbett, C. Trafton

content.description:
A pleasant variation that links the first three bolts of Goo-Ni-Goo-Goo with the last bolt of Drytoolers Will be Prosecuted.



Far right side of waterfall wall.

6 bolts, Quick Clip anchor

An excellent technical climb at the grade. 
Climb blocky rock at the bottom then trend left to the beautiful face. Continue straight up the face, making use of minuscule crimps at the crux. Easier but still technical and balancy climbing to the top.

On the right side of Waterfall Wall. This is the leftmost of 3 sport climbs. It often stays dry even though the rock immediately to the left can be wet.
bolts. bolted anchor

A decent route with a few interesting moves. The rock quality is not great near the top.

On the right end of Waterfall Wall. This is the middle of 3 sport climbs.
bolts, bolted anchor

climbs.name: House Sass
climbs.fa: A. Savoie, D. Caron, A. Schneider 2018

content.description:
Climb easy ledges and sometimes questionable rock to a set of quick-clip anchors.
This well bolted route is well suited for people learning to sport climb.

At the right end of Waterfall Wall. The rightmost of the 3 sport climbs.
bolts, quick clip anchor

An excellent and sustained face climb!

Start up Waterfall Layback to the ramp. Partway up the ramp, clip a bolt on the face and trend up and right for a few moves then up the technical face.
The face is bolted but you will need some gear for the bottom and the top of the route.

Variation: 
Slippery when Wet Direct 5.12
This variation starts at the base of the ramp and climbs 2 bolts of very technical moves before joining Slippery When Wet.

Bolted face just right of the right-facing corner of Waterfall Layback
Single rack up to #.75. Bolted anchor.

A nice route which is seldom climbed. Sometimes wet due to its proximity to the waterfall.
Climb a low bulge to gain good holds. Trend left a bit, aiming for a lone bolt. Climb the face past the bolt and discontinuous cracks and continue up the right-facing corner. Move right at the top to the anchors to the anchors.

Just right of the waterfall and left of the 3 sport routes. look for the face with a single bolt.
Standard rack to about BD #1. One bolt. Bolted anchor

A good route with sadly a few spots of crumbly rock.
Follow the bolted line up the face, using the arête for a few moves now and then.
A few pieces of gear at the bottom and top of the route.

At the far left of Waterfall Wall. This route climbs the face just left of the prominent right-facing corner of Waterfall Layback.
Single rack. Tree anchor.

This classic route climbs the obvious right-facing corner/ramp on the left side of the wall. Unfortunately the bottom of the route tends to be wet except when it's been very dry for a long time.
Climb up horizontals to gain the base of the ramp. The crux comes when the left side of the corner turns overhanging and the feet disappear. Layback this section until you reach a jug. A few easier moves take you to the anchor.

On the left side of Waterfall Wall. This route climbs the obvious right-facing ramp and corner.
Single Rack to BD #3. Depending on how much you want to sew it up, doubles in #.75-2 could be handy. Bolted anchor

Start on easy terrain protected by natural gear up to a slightly overhanging beautiful section protected by bolts and natural gear. Plug in a bomber 0.4 BD cam and go for the powerful crux eventually finishing on a technical bolt-protected face. As you can imagine, this route is often wet. However, don’t miss the opportunity to drop everything and hop on this gem when it’s dry. 



Found in the middle of Waterfall Wall. 

4 bolts supplemented with a single rack. Bolted anchor.

This wall located pretty much central within the Cochrane Lane cliffs is home to the classic Waterfall Layback as well as a few excellent face climbs (just off vertical). The waterfall can often be seen from the farmer's field, especially when it is frozen. This area is also suitable for ice climbing in the winter. For much of the summer the waterfall is more of a trickle, but sadly keeps the base of the cliff pretty wet for the routes on the left end. The three sport climbs on the right end of the cliff tend to dry fast and can even be climbed on a nice winter day since they get a lot of sun.
